THE SUN, BALTIMORE, SUNDAY MORNING, SEPTEMBER

div1.p: WINDSOR MILL PLACE

An Old Mansion Associated With
Baltimore's Early History.
PROPOSED PARK BOULEVARD

Will Pass Through The Estate --
Boyhood Home Of Dr. Jesse Wil-
liam Lazear, Yellow-Fever Hero.
By EMILY EMERSON LANTZ.

Truly there is a great gulf fixed between
things celestial and things of the earth
earthy! Most of us affirm, and with entire
sincerity, that the end and aim of our
earthly endeavor is to attain “a house not
made with hands” in the world to come,
yet until this mortal shall have put on
immortality the very height of our am-
bition is to possess a hand-made house. One
of those wide, hospitable dwellings whose
stone walls afford cool protection from the
sun of midsummer and warmth and shelter
from the blasts of winter, the laths of
which are turned and the nails and keys
wrought by handcraft.

Such houses possess an individuality and
character wholly impossible to the so-to-
ALONG THE LINE OF THE PROPOSED BOULEVARD
speak ready-made houses that are evolved
with the suddenness and as little apparent
human effort as the wonders of the stage
magician.

There are many old houses interesting
both of themselves and through the person-
ality of those inhabiting them around Bal-
timore, and among them is the Windsor
Mill place, on the Gwynn's falls, which
belongs to the heirs of General Jesse La-
zear, a prominent banker and Congress-
man of Western Pennsylvania, whose only
daughter, Mrs. Alexander Seth, resides on
the old estate. Peculiar interest centers in
the estate, because through part of it will
be laid out the proposed park extension
driveway which is destined in the near fu-
ture to make the Gwynn's Falls Park road
for Baltimore what the Wissahicken drive
is to Philadelphia. For years Mrs. Seth
and her brothers, joint heirs of the estate,
have held themselves in readiness to do-
nate a portion of their land to such a proj-
ect of local improvement and one of the
WINDSOR MILL PLACE
most picturesque portions of the proposed
forest drive will be that which will pass
through Windsor Mill place, which extends
for over 4,000 feet along Gwynn's falls.

The old residence of the Windsor Mill
place is a stone mansion that crowns one
portion of the Windsor Hills and which
took its name from a stone mill that once
turned tranquil wheels of usefulness on
Gwynn's falls at the intersection of the
ancient Powhatan road and the Wethereds-
ville road that extends along Gwynn's falls.
As all roads once led to Rome, so in olden
days all roads in the vicinity of what is
now Walbrook led to Windsor Mill, the
center of neighborhood commercial interest.
The mansion overlooking the site of the
former mill property is older than the mem-
ory of its oldest possessor. The oldest deed
extant to the property is dated August 7,
1787, and conveys a broad piece of landed
estate from William Baxley, gentleman, of
Baltimore county, Maryland, to William
Bingham, gentleman, of Philadelphia, and
Robert Gilmor, gentleman, of Baltimore
town and county.

The tract was known as Roger's Enlarge-
ment and described in the deed as follow-
ing the windings and meadows of Gwynn's
falls, and it included a piece of land called
Crowley's First Venture.

A later purchaser was the late Rev.
Dr. Francis Waters, who was one of the
organizers of and gave its name to the
Methodist Protestant Church. The cler-
gyman was the father of Dr. Edmund G.
Waters, residing at 1711 Madison avenue.
Rev. Dr. Waters bought the estate, then
about 175 acres and extending on both
sides of the falls, in 1835 from Oliver Kin-
sey.

Half of the original house had at that
time been destroyed by fire, but the old
house as occupied by Dr. Waters remains
unchanged, although a front wing and back
building, causing the whole to resemble the
letter Z, have been added.

The original stone house has a width of
about 75 feet and is but one room deep,
with a stone and log kitchen in the rear.

It has three spacious apartments on the
first floor, with the same number of rooms
above, and a stairway at each end of the
building. Curiously enough, a passageway
extends across the front of the second story
and the bedrooms look westward upon a
sweet, placid English court effect formed by
the angle of the house. Here a velvet lawn
is bounded by alleys of boxwood, after the
fashion of the formal garden at Mount Ver-
non, and the air is fragrant with the snowy
blossoming of old-fashioned “day lillies.”

Clambering ivy and other vines scale the
walls, seeking to peep in the dormer win-
dows of an attic that extends the length of
the house. This garret is a treasure trove
for those who love the things of the past,
and among the quaint things are old hair-
covered and leather-covered trunks beaded
with brass tacks, iron-bound and rope-tied
trunks, as well as “boxes,” as the English
would say, of tin and chests of wood; and
in them things old and quaint enough to
stock the curiosity shop of a Dickens.

Old wedding and ball gowns of brocade,
rich and stiff enough to stand alone:
steeple-crowned and poke bonnets, all
wreathed within with flowers--a fitting
frame for some fair flower-like face; dainty
lingerie embroidered by hand and laces
filmy and weblike, once worn as berthas
over low-cut gowns.

The stone walls of the house are of the
thickness of a foot and each room on the
ground floor has a capacious fireplace, with
brass shovel and tongs. The doors are of
a solidity that delights the eye, and their
handles are of solid brass, egg-shaped, or
else loops of brass of the same quaint pat-
tern as those at Mount Vernon. The great
brass knocker at the entrance is said to be
more modern, but it represents an Ameri-
can eagle--bird of freedom--and looks old
enough to have welcomed patriot and Tory
guests to the mansion in generations past.

The mahogany sideboard, graced with
silver candlesticks, ancient settees and
Chippendale tables that furnish the resi-
dence are in keeping with its antiquity,
and upon the upper floors are stanch ma-
hogany wardrobes that inclose chests of
drawers in the middle and open at each
end for the hanging of dainty gowns.

The window sills everywhere are deep
as embattled casements, and one of the
quaintest relics of the past is the stone
spring house with moss-covered conical
roof, while the iron key, nearly a foot long
and over 100 years old, of the stone smoke-
house is ponderous enough to grant admis-
sion to a bastile. Gates through the place
yield to weights, instead of latch or bolts,
so that the quaintness of the building is not
marred by modern surroundings.

The “new” wing is 40 years old. It was
built to afford a spacious drawing room for
his only daughter (now Mrs. Alexander
Seth) by Gen. Jesse Lazear. The somewhat
stately furnishings of the period and the
original wall paper outlined in gold leaf
continue unchanged, and wide porches ex-
tend the length of both the old and new
portions of the house.

Rev. Dr. Francis Waters, who bought
the Windsor Mill place in 1835 and resided
there until 1852, was one of the finest
Greek and Latin scholars of his day and
one of the leading educators of Maryland.
He was at one time president of Washing-
ton College, at Chestertown, Md., and later
principal of the Princess Anne Academy.
Isaac Jones, Attorney-General of Mary-
land, was one of those educated by him,
and Congressman Crisfield, of Somerset
county. In order to have his own sons
educated under his supervision by tutors
and yet enjoy the companionship of other
lads Dr. Waters conducted a school in a
stone schoolhouse building then on the
place, while some of the boys were resi-
dents of his home. The tutor was a native
Greek who had received his education in
England and at Princeton, and the school
flourished until the death of Dr. Waters'
eldest son caused him to lose interest in
the undertaking. The schoolhouse still
stands unoccupied upon a portion of the
estate which has since become the prop-
erty of Mrs. Gaun Hutton and which ex-
tends to the Frankiln turnpike.

The next owner of the old place was Mr.
James H. Carter, of the banking and brok-
erage firm of Lee & Johnston. He bought it
of Dr. Waters for $10,000, and at his death
the property included 218 acres and ex-
tended on both sides of Gwynn's falls. To
him is due many of the exterior improve-
ments that make the place peculiarly beau-
tiful. He planted rare trees, a fine avenue
of Norway firs and cedars, a buckeye tree
whose springtime blossoms attract myriads
of jewel-like humming birds. There are
splendid beech trees and a lofty sugar ma-
ple from whose sap many a pound of maple
sugar has been secured. There are arbor
vitae hedges and a magnificent weeping
willow watered by an ancient pump. Tow-
ering walnut trees cast their rich shade
and a wisteria vine flings an archway of
purple blossoms across the drive along the
sides of which are beds of myrtle and wild
violets.

One of the many improvements made
by Mr. Carter was the erection of a gate-
keeper's lodge--a rather picturesque struc-
ture of semi-Italian design at the entrance
to the drive that opens upon the old Weth-
eredsville road, facing the falls.

This lodge, now in disuse for its orig-
inal purpose, will fall within the area of
land donated by General Lazear's heirs to
the Park Board for a boulevard. It offers
exceptional opportunity, both from a pic-
turesque and practical point of view, to the
Park Board. The forest drives of Europe
abound with quaint chalets and inns,
where pleasure-seekers, made hungry by
exercise in the open air, may obtain some
light refreshment. There is a very definite
need in Baltimore parks of some places
where those seeking outdoor recreation,
and especially those accompanied by small
children, could be sure of finding some-
where for sale such simple refreshment
as a glass of pure milk and a bun. There
is small doubt that should the Windsor Mill
Lodge be fitted up as an attractive tea
room, where a cup of good tea, a glass of
fresh milk, cream or country buttermilk
could be secured with a biscuit or cracker,
there is small doubt that it would fill a
long-felt want in this community. The
standard of the milk and cream would have
to be maintained by frequent official inspec-
tion, and the license to sell such edibles
made subject to revocation by the Park
Board if such regulations were not com-
plied with. This is a chance for Major
Venable to become the benefactor of old and
young alike. There used to be, and per-
haps still is, near Monterey, in the Blue
Ridge Mountains, a tollgate where the gate-
keeper's wife sold cream and buttermilk,
and her clean dairy was the Mecca of all
pilgrimages through the woods and along
mountain roads.

Mr. Carter's occupancy of Windsor Mills
was marked by an effort to reclaim the
waste meadowland lying between the old
Wetheredville road and the stream. He
built at his own expense a public road nearer
the falls than the old one and sodded the
intervening meadows as a spreading lawn.
The great flood of July 24, 1868, swept
away every vestige of the new-made road-
way and not an ounce of earth was left to
mark the spot of the sodded lawn. After
this disaster travel was resumed on the old
Wetheredville road, where it continues.

Windsor Heights was at that time in-
cluded in the estate, but through sales to
Mr. Francis White and others the place is
now limited to about 100 acres.

Through the late Chauncey Brooks, who
was the executor of Mr. Carter, Gen. Jesse
Lazear, of Uniontown, Pa., became the
next owner of Windsor Mill Place.

General Lazear was the grandfather of
Dr. Jesse William Lazear, and the old estate
has the distinction of being associated
with the childhood of a man great and
noble enough to lay down his life in the
cause of medical science and humanity.
Dr. Lazear was a Marylander, born in 1866,
and the son of the late William Lazear and
nephew of Mr. T. C. Lazear, of Pittsburg.
After studying at Trinity Hall Military
School, the Johns Hopkins and Columbia
Universities he won high honors in the
medical profession. Later Dr. Lazear be-
came a surgeon in the United States Army
and was assigned to special laboratory
work at Columbia barracks, near Havana,
Cuba. He was appointed in 1900 a mem-
ber of a special Government commission
for the investigation of yellow fever. This
commission made discoveries of the great-
est scientific importance in connection with
yellow fever, but there came a point in the
investigation where further progress in the
theory that yellow fever is transmitted
solely through the bite of the mosquito
depended wholly upon human experiment.
Dr. Lazear and a comrade volunteered to
subject themselves to infection through
the bite of the mosquitoes that had pre-
viously bitten sufferers from yellow fever,
and both men became infected with the dis-
ease and died. Dr. Welch, of the Johns
Hopkins Hospital, has referred to the re-
port of this commission as the most im-
portant contribution to medicine since the
discovery of anæsthesia. At Johns Hopkins
Hospital and at Trinity Hall Military
School, Washington, Pa., there are tablets
honoring the noble man who thus laid down
his life for humanity.

From the highest points of the Windsor
Mill Place can be had a magnificent view
of country and city, and down the Balti-
more waterways to the point where river
and bay unite. The place abounds in stone,
and it is said that many of the cobblestones
for paving Baltimore in the vicinity of
West Fayette and Lexington streets were
hauled in four-horse loads from off the
Windsor Mill estate. There are beautiful
springs upon the ground, and Somerfield
Camp, so named from the noted English
divine, was held in the groves on the top
of the heights. The colored brethren of the
neighborhood are fond also of holding re-
ligious meetings beneath these forest trees.
There are those who remember a discourse
concerning the Master and His “twelve ap-
prentices,” and another occasion when the
turning of Lot's wife into a pillar of salt
was under discussion and the speaker cas-
ually remarked:
“That's where all our salt comes from.”

The Windsor Mill, spoken of in docu-
ments of 1818 as the “old Windsor Mill,”
remained long an unimposing ruin just be-
yond the bridge that spans Gwynns Falls
beyond Mount Holly. It was removed at
a very recent date, but the name lives on
in the estate which forms the subject of
this sketch.
